misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a complete program to compute the distance between two points instead of a program that reads a single numeric grade and outputs a letter grade using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: I think this question is asking me to read two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and compute the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read one numeric grade between 0 and 100 and then use conditional statements to map that grade into a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the specified ranges.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, and y2 instead of a single grade.
All input variables are doubles named as coordinates, not a grade.
The only computation performed is a distance formula using Math.sqrt, not any conditional grading logic.
The output describes distance between points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading the assignment or copying a solution for a different problem from notes or a textbook example (distance between two points) instead of implementing the required grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the program around that specification: read a single numeric grade, then use an if–else-if chain (or switch with ranges) to decide which letter grade to print. Make sure prompts and variable names reflect grades, not coordinates.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure of the program (inputs, variable names, computation, and output text) matches the classic distance-between-points exercise and has no overlap with the required grade calculator behavior.

evidence.note: All input, computation, and output are for a distance-between-points problem; there is no reading of a grade or conditional letter-grade logic.

misconceptions.name: Submission of Irrelevant Code / Complete Task Misinterpretation
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a program that correctly calculates the distance between two points (a likely solution to a different problem), but this code is entirely irrelevant and fails to address the requirements of Q3, the Grade Calculator assignment. No grading logic (input reading, conditional checks, or output mapping) was implemented.
misconceptions.student_belief: The submitted code fulfills the assignment requirements, perhaps due to submitting a solution for a previous or different problem instead of the Grade Calculator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The requirement for Q3 was to read a single numeric grade (0-100) and use conditional statements (if/else if/else) to map that grade to the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F).
symptoms: No grade input is taken; inputs are coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2)
The program calculates geometric distance using Math.sqrt
The code contains no conditional logic (if/else if/else) necessary for grading
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely mixed up files or pasted code from an entirely separate exercise into the submission for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please delete the existing code and start fresh, focusing only on reading a single grade input and implementing the if/else logic required to determine and print the letter grade based on the specified ranges (90-100 for A, 80-89 for B, etc.).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, input prompts, variable names, and core calculation (Math.sqrt for distance) are all irrefutable evidence that the student submitted a solution for a distance calculation problem instead of the grade calculation problem.

evidence.note: The class name indicates a program calculating distance, not grades.
Input prompts and variable names are specific to coordinates, not a single numeric grade.

evidence.snippet: double distanceBetweenPoints = Math.sqrt(xDifference * xDifference + yDifference * yDifference);
evidence.note: The calculation performed is the distance formula, not grade determination based on bounds.

misconceptions.name: Task Misalignment - Solved Wrong Problem
misconceptions.description: The student wrote code to calculate the distance between two points, when the assignment required a grade calculator that reads a numeric grade and outputs a letter grade. This indicates either a fundamental misunderstanding of the problem requirements or failure to read the problem statement carefully.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were solving a distance-between-points problem or did not carefully read the Q3 problem specification before implementing.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the specified ranges. This is completely different from calculating Euclidean distance between coordinate pairs.
symptoms: Program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade value
Program calculates distance formula instead of grade mapping
Output displays distance instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade range checking
No letter grade output
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to read and understand the problem requirements before coding. The student may have referenced the wrong problem or copied code from a different assignment.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read problem Q3 carefully. Start over by: (1) reading ONE integer/double for the grade, (2) using if-else statements to check which range it falls into, (3) printing the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty—the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (distance calculator) than what was assigned (grade calculator). The mismatch is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Code reads two coordinate points (x1, y1) instead of a single numeric grade as required by Q3

evidence.snippet:
double distanceBetweenPoints = Math.sqrt(xDifference * xDifference + yDifference * yDifference);
        System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distanceBetweenPoints);
evidence.note: Program calculates and outputs Euclidean distance instead of a letter grade mapping

misconceptions.task: Overall problem solving for Grade Calculator
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance-between-points instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student fully implemented a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a program that reads a numeric grade (0–100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade according to the specified ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: Submitting my distance-between-points program here is acceptable, and a working Java program (even if it solves a different problem) is enough for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must specifically read a single numeric grade in the range 0–100 and use conditional statements to map that grade to a letter (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the given ranges. Any other computation, such as distance between points, does not satisfy the problem requirements.
symptoms: Program class is named DistanceBetweenPoints instead of something related to grades.
Prompts ask for x1, y1, x2, y2 rather than a single grade value.
Program computes a geometric distance using Math.sqrt and coordinate differences.
No conditional logic exists for grade ranges (A/B/C/D/F).
No output of a letter grade; output describes distance between two points.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or reuse of an earlier template without adjusting it to the grade-calculator specification. The student may focus on producing any working Java program rather than aligning the program’s behavior with the exact problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint:
Rubric scoring for this submission:
- Reading numeric grade input: 0/1 (program reads four coordinates instead of a single numeric grade)
- Correct Boolean ranges for A and B: 0/1 (no conditions on grade values are present)
- Correct Boolean ranges for C and D: 0/1 (no mid-range grade checks are implemented)
- Correct handling of F (default/else): 0/1 (no fallback or else branch for grades below 60)
- Mapping each range to correct letter output: 0/1 (program never prints a letter grade)

How to fix it:
1. Change the input to read a single numeric grade, e.g.:
   - Prompt: "Enter grade: "
   - Use one variable (int or double) for the grade, not x1, y1, etc.
2. Replace the distance computation with an if/else-if/else chain that checks the given ranges:
   - 90–100 -> print "Letter grade: A"
   - 80–89  -> print "Letter grade: B"
   - 70–79  -> print "Letter grade: C"
   - 60–69  -> print "Letter grade: D"
   - below 60 -> print "Letter grade: F"
3. Test your program with several sample inputs (e.g., 95, 85, 75, 65, 50) and confirm the outputs match the specification.

Overall feedback:
- Strength: You demonstrate that you can use Scanner to read numeric input and perform arithmetic with variables and Math.sqrt.
- Main improvement area: Carefully match your program to the exact problem description. Before coding, restate the task in your own words and, after coding, check that every required behavior (input, decisions, and output) is present and correct.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categories using if-else statements
Designing program input and output to match requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure, prompts, variables, and calculations are focused on distance between points and contain no references to grades, ranges, or letter outputs, making it very unlikely this was an accidental omission.

evidence.note: The class name, prompts, variables, and computation all target distance between two points; there is no input of a grade, no conditional logic for grade ranges, and no letter-grade output.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Problem Implementation
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating the distance between two points (likely a previous assignment question) instead of implementing the required Grade Calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may believe that the submitted code, which solves a geometric calculation problem, is sufficient or relevant for the grade calculation problem, or they simply failed to replace the previous code with the correct solution.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code reads four double values instead of one integer/double grade.
Code performs distance calculation instead of grade classification.
The output is a distance value, not a letter grade.
All rubric points related to grade classification are unaddressed.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to start the correct implementation for Q3, possibly due to copy-pasting code from Q2 and forgetting to modify it, or a complete misunderstanding of the assignment instructions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the program entirely. Focus on steps 1) Read the input grade. 2) Use if-else statements to check the grade against the specified ranges. 3) Print the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student submits code named 'DistanceBetweenPoints' that performs distance calculation when the prompt asks for a 'Grade Calculator'. This is an undeniable misimplementation of the assigned task.

evidence.note: The class name suggests a solution for a different geometry problem.
Input reading is for coordinate pairs, not a single grade input (0-100).
The core logic calculates distance, not a letter grade.
